segment.source: 4648(S) A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
segment.target: 4648(S) A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4648(S) A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
segment.target: Describes security event 4648(S) A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.

segment.source: 4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
segment.target: 4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event is generated when a process attempts an account logon by explicitly specifying that account’s credentials.
segment.target: This event is generated when a process attempts an account logon by explicitly specifying that account’s credentials.

segment.source: This most commonly occurs in batch-type configurations such as scheduled tasks, or when using the “RUNAS” command.
segment.target: This most commonly occurs in batch-type configurations such as scheduled tasks, or when using the “RUNAS” command.

segment.source: It is also a routine event which periodically occurs during normal operating system activity.
segment.target: It is also a routine event which periodically occurs during normal operating system activity.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the new logon session with explicit credentials.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the new logon session with explicit credentials.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the new logon session with explicit credentials.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the new logon session with explicit credentials.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.
segment.target: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.

segment.source: It also can be used for correlation between a 4648 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on” and “4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.”
segment.target: It also can be used for correlation between a 4648 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on” and “4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.

segment.source:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.
segment.target:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.

segment.source: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.
segment.target: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.

segment.source: Account Whose Credentials Were Used:
segment.target: Account Whose Credentials Were Used:

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account whose credentials were used.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account whose credentials were used.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.
segment.target: Logon GUID Type = GUID: a GUID that can help you correlate this event with another event that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested event on a domain controller.

segment.source: It also can be used for correlation between a 4648 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on” and “4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.”
segment.target: It also can be used for correlation between a 4648 event and several other events (on the same computer) that can contain the same Logon GUID, “4624(S): An account was successfully logged on” and “4964(S): Special groups have been assigned to a new logon.”

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}”.

segment.source:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.
segment.target:
Note
GUID is an acronym for 'Globally Unique Identifier'.

segment.source: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.
segment.target: It is a 128-bit integer number used to identify resources, activities or instances.

segment.source: Target Server:
segment.target: Target Server:

segment.source: Target Server Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the server on which the new process was run.
segment.target: Target Server Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the server on which the new process was run.

segment.source: Has “localhost” value if the process was run locally.
segment.target: Has “localhost” value if the process was run locally.

segment.source: Additional Information Type = UnicodeString: there is no detailed information about this field in this document.
segment.target: Additional Information Type = UnicodeString: there is no detailed information about this field in this document.

segment.source: Process Information:
segment.target: Process Information:

segment.source: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which was run using explicit credentials.
segment.target: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which was run using explicit credentials.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Process Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Network Information:
segment.target: Network Information:

segment.source: Network Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of machine from which logon attempt was performed.
segment.target: Network Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of machine from which logon attempt was performed.

segment.source: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.
segment.target: IPv6 address or ::ffff:IPv4 address of a client.

segment.source: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.
segment.target: ::1 or 127.0.0.1 means localhost.

segment.source: Port Type = UnicodeString: source port which was used for logon attempt from remote machine.
segment.target: Port Type = UnicodeString: source port which was used for logon attempt from remote machine.

segment.source: 0 for interactive logons.
segment.target: 0 for interactive logons.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
segment.target: For 4648(S): A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.

segment.source: The following table is similar to the table in Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events, but also describes ways of monitoring that use “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID.”
segment.target: The following table is similar to the table in Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events, but also describes ways of monitoring that use “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID.”

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that correspond to the high value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that correspond to the high value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform the action corresponding to this event.
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform the action corresponding to this event.

segment.source: Monitor for the “SubjectAccount Domain” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor for the “SubjectAccount Domain” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” or “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: For example, you might monitor to ensure that “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” is not used to log on to a certain computer.
segment.target: For example, you might monitor to ensure that “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” is not used to log on to a certain computer.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” and “Account Whose Credentials Were UsedSecurity ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined “Process Name” for the process reported in this event, monitor all events with “Process Name” not equal to your defined value.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “Process Name” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in process names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Process Name.”

segment.source: If SubjectSecurity ID should not know or use credentials for Account Whose Credentials Were UsedAccount Name, monitor this event.
segment.target: If SubjectSecurity ID should not know or use credentials for Account Whose Credentials Were UsedAccount Name, monitor this event.

segment.source: If credentials for Account Whose Credentials Were UsedAccount Name should not be used from Network InformationNetwork Address, monitor this event.
segment.target: If credentials for Account Whose Credentials Were UsedAccount Name should not be used from Network InformationNetwork Address, monitor this event.

segment.source: Check that Network InformationNetwork Address is from internal IP address list.
segment.target: Check that Network InformationNetwork Address is from internal IP address list.

segment.source: For example, if you know that a specific account (for example, a service account) should be used only from specific IP addresses, you can monitor for all events where Network InformationNetwork Address is not one of the allowed IP addresses.
segment.target: For example, if you know that a specific account (for example, a service account) should be used only from specific IP addresses, you can monitor for all events where Network InformationNetwork Address is not one of the allowed IP addresses.
